review: **spoiler alert** Maybe it's sad, but this is really the first piece of fiction I've ever reader (with maybe the exception of a few Edgar Allan Poe st**spoiler alert** Maybe it's sad, but this is really the first piece of fiction I've ever reader (with maybe the exception of a few Edgar Allan Poe stories) told by a narrator I actually found unreliable. Lots of times, people will say the narrator of a book is unreliable because it makes a book seem more complicated (there's more to it than just surface--the narrator is so unreliable), but usually people just mean the narrator espouses a different view of life, one with which the reader may not entirely agree. That's not the same thing as an unreliable narrator. "The Sportswriter," on the other hand, seems entirely predicated on the fact Frank Bascombe is full of shit and much of the novel's power comes in measuring the distance between Frank's perceptions and what's actually happening to him. For instance, I love the scene where Frank goes to the police after Watler's suicide and the cop on duty is kind of grinning and Frank's convinced it's because the cops have been joking around but it's clearly because the cop thinks Frank was Walter's lover (this is early '80s New Jersey after all). One thing I find odd is how many s of the book refer to Frank as a descent man or some semblance of that line. That seems a total misreading of the novel, because Frank is a real shitbird--as self-absorbed and oblivious as the suburbs he professes to love. Granted, much of Frank's "dreaminess" results from the death of his son, but Frank deals with his loss in the most self-serving ways possible. I thought this the first time I read this book, about ten years ago, but I'd heard so many people--people whose opinion I trusted--speak of Bascbome in such glowing terms I thought I was wrong. Then recently I heard Ford talking on the Diane Riem show (I endured her head-up-the-ass brand of upper Northwest nonsense for the entire hour--that's how much I like Richard Ford) saying something like (and I'm paraphrasing), If I ever find myself agreeing with anything Frank Bascombe says, I've failed. All of that said, Issacson provides valuable insights into what made Jobs so successful, particularly emphasizing that he was one of the few people in the tech industry to consider the importance of the liberal arts, a concern that profoundly influenced the look and functionality of many Apple products. review: Kudos to Krakauer for keeping me reading given how much I disliked the subject of his book. Yes, it's awful what happened to Chris Mccandles, but despKudos to Krakauer for keeping me reading given how much I disliked the subject of his book. Yes, it's awful what happened to Chris Mccandles, but despite the author's intentions to the contrary, the kid still comes off like every other pain in the ass know it all hacky-sacker I've met who possessed the totally unacknowledged privilege to decide to pretend to escape their (ultimately inescapable) safety nets. The problem with Mccandles wasn't that he didn't properly respect the land (as many who objected to his expedition claim), though there's a bit of that, too. The simple issue with him is that this is someone who, given being born at a certain time, of a certain race, to certain parents of a certain socio-economic class, never had to actually worry about failure--even when the potential for it is acknowledged as he begins his journey it seems perfunctory, the type of thing the kind of Thorouian guy he is choosing to cast himself as is obligated to say. Now granted, perhaps the shackles of that existence are what drove him to such extremes, but was creating a thoroughly manufactured nomadic existence really bringing him closer to some type of natural reality? Is that a more noble or more thrilling existence then taking the fruits of his privilege (including a $25,000 trust fund that he just gave away), and actually working for the betterment of something? Still, I should also say Krakauer is a hell of a writer. I disagree with almost every single defense he provides of his subject, but his investigation into Mccandles and others who have gone into the wild, including himself, give this book an impressive, and effective, scope. This book isn't only about the man at the center of it, but very much about the pull nature has always had on a certain kind of American man. The biggest thing going for Last Days was the atmosphere; it's actually one of the creepiest books I've ever read. Maybe that's because I find amputation so disturbing--then again, who doesn't?--and the novel really taps into that deep seeded fear about the partial death we experience when lose little bits of ourselves. Also, Evenson clearly understands and effectively conveys how religious devotion can drive people to actions that seem bonkers to the uninitiated; he even draws some interesting parallels between that inclination and the lengths to which some will go in the name of basic human curiosity. On other hand, the biggest drawback of the novel was the narrator who was far too much of a blank slate, definitely more so than the narrators in the Dasheill Hammett novels on which he seems to be based. It's fine to not get the narrator's back story, I actually kind of like that, but we get so little of his thought process, his personality, it was hard at times to maintain interest in the story beyond the plot (which is admittedly very well executed). Granted, we never get any of the Continental Op's home life, but we have a sense of of his point of view, what drives him, etc. Now, given the general pulp feel of the novel, some might say the characterization of the narrator is beyond the point, but there's too much other interesting stuff going on for me to buy the author was simply trying to write a smash'em up crime book. In fact, this belief is a major drawback of the book. Stross diminishes a number of Edison's accomplishments based largely on the fact that a significant percentage of his creations never made money or failed all together. However, this is often the case with inventions. You invent forty or fifty things in the hopes that one has a life or that something will grow out of a less effective device; this seems like something a writer familiar with technology should know. In addition, Stross attributes Edison's fame more to his ability to work the press than the fact he ran the labs that invented the phonograph, and the electric light and a system to power it. Hiltzik's book explains how over the course of ten years some of the world's foremost computer scientists invented almost every feature that we have come to associate with personal computing--overlapping windows, "what you see is what you get" word processing, the desktop, high speed printing, connection to an Ethernet, point and click technology, the ubiquity of the mouse, and the use of icons as opposed to coding. What's most fascinating is how Hiltzik details the creative process that led to these inventions, specifically how so many of them built off each other and the spirit of competition within the lab that resulted in great leaps forward. While the author is occasionally too worshipful of his subjects, it's not hard to see why with the cast of characters he has to work with. Heavily featured in the book are Bob Taylor (the man who ran the department of the Pentagon that literally invented the Internet), and Alan Kay (a research scientist whose dissertation anticipated by more than 30 years the hand held computer technology that Apple would bring to fruition with its Ipad), two of the most important individuals in the history of personal computing. While it may sound as though this book is written exclusively for those with an interest in or knowledge of computers, that is not the case. Much of the book explores the tensions between Xerox's corporate headquarters and PARC management in addition to the rivalries between and among the departments at PARC. What's more, I have an incredibly rudimentary understanding of technology and almost every aspect of this book made sense to me (with the exception of object oriented programming--I'm still not sure what that is or why it's important and I've done further reading on it). The reason for that mostly relates to the middle section of the book, which far too often sagged under the weight of the ideas and themes Somerville explores—what is evil, what determines how a person becomes who they are, what responsibility do the privileged have to acknowledge their privilege, how much knowledge is too much, is it better to confront the past or ignore it (and I’m probably missing a few others). This isn’t to say a novel shouldn't explore weighty ideas—in fact that’s one of the most important things the best novels do. However, the exploration of ideas should always, to quote Steve Almond, arise from “the emotional lives of the characters.” Far too often, and particularly in the middle hundred or so pages of "This Bright River," the characters spent a lot of time in a room talking about ideas, rather than taking actions that convey ideas. That’s not really why I read novels. Another roadblock I encountered in “This Bright River” is the order in which the story is presented. Far too much of the story, at least in the order in which Somerville and the narrator delineate it (which, it should be said, is not always the order in which the events actually occurred or even the order in which the characters ascertain knowledge of those things) gives a coincidental feel to a number of important plot points. Coincidence is fine for an episode of Breaking Bad, but I expect a book, especially one that is relatively realistic, to work a little harder at foreshadowing and prepare us for what’s to come so key moments don’t feel like the author working himself out of a jam. review: Tzioumakis starts his study at the dawn of the studio system (1908) and examines the evolving ways in which all types of people involved in the producTzioumakis starts his study at the dawn of the studio system (1908) and examines the evolving ways in which all types of people involved in the production of films--producers, writers, actors, etc.--have acted independent of that system, before, in many cases, becoming the system themselves. The book provides an ever-changing, though almost always economically-based, definition of the word independent and given its scope, that makes sense; the hallmarks of cinematic independence in 1909 vastly differ from the hallmarks of cinematic independence in 1999. Each chapter of the book provides a case study in a particular figure or film, but the vast majority of the work explores the economic and systemic factors leading to an Independent American Cinema. That's the main strength of this book but also its biggest flaw--it focuses far too much on the business end of independent cinema, which means the author basically ignores films that have little to no connection to the film business--neither Maya Darren nor Stan Brackage are once mentioned in over 250 pages. In essence, Tzioumakis allows the major studios to define independence, which is certainly an odd, not mention problematic, way to go. However, the book has some really fascinating info, especially on the ultra low budget exploitation films of the 50s and 60s as well as on the ethnic cinema of the 20s, 30s, and 40s....more
